result.execSummary:
The defendant James Earl Queen was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • OWI (5th or 6th), a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: The Court ordered the defendant to pay a fine of $2400 plus applicable costs, fees, and surcharges (including DNA) during the term of extended supervision.  Cash bond on deposit is to be applied.  Failure to pay shall result in a civil judgment. If revoked from extended supervision, Court ordered that all court costs, fines, fees, and surcharges be paid through collection by the Department of Corrections in an amount or percentage the Department (DOC) determines to be reasonable and as a condition of extended supervision.  DOC shall collect those sums.  Any amount remaining due and owing is subject to civil judgment and/or tax intercept or other means.

superMiscConds.notes:
- AODA assessment and cooperate with any programs deemed necessary by the probation department.
- Absolute sobriety. 
- Random urine screens and breathalyzer tests.

supervisions.notes: The Court ordered defendant's operating privileges revoked for a period of 2 YEARS followed by ignition interlock for a period of 2 YEARS.
- Court advised the defendant that as a convicted felon, he may never own or possess a firearm.  Court advised defendant that he may not vote until his civil rights have been restored.

records.addlTxt:
Defendant James Earl Queen in court with Attorney Barry S. Cohen.  Student Intern Caroline Pellegrini under the supervision of Attorney William R. F. Ackell appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
Case in court for plea/sentencing.  Parties have reached an agreement.  Plea negotiations set forth on the record and agreed upon by the parties.

AS TO COUNT 1:
Defendant changes plea to GUILTY. Defendant examined as to plea, advised of Constitutional Rights and the maximum penalties. Defendant further advised that if not a US citizen, deportation is possible. Court found that the defendant knowingly, voluntarily and intelligently waived rights.  Plea Questionnaire/Waiver of Rights form, Addendum, and Elements/Jury Instructions received and filed. Parties stipulate to the Criminal Complaint as a factual basis to sustain defendant's plea.  Court found defendant GUILTY and ordered a Judgment of Conviction be entered on the record.  

Court advised the defendant that as a convicted felon, he may never own or possess a firearm.  Court advised defendant that he may not vote until his civil rights have been restored.  Sentencing proceeded.   Statements by the State, Defense Counsel and Defendant.  Additional statements by:  Denise Q.

AS TO COUNT 1: 
The Court sentenced the defendant to a MAXIMUM TERM OF IMPRISONMENT of 38 MONTHS with 4 days credit; the INITIAL TERM OF CONFINEMENT in the Wisconsin State Prison System is 14 MONTHS; the MAXIMUM TERM OF EXTENDED SUPERVISION is 24 MONTHS.  

Court finds defendant IS eligible for the the WI Substance Abuse program and IS NOT eligible for the Challenge Incarceration program. 

CONDITIONS OF EXTENDED SUPERVISION: 
- AODA assessment and cooperate with any programs deemed necessary by the probation department.
- Absolute sobriety. 
- Random urine screens and breathalyzer tests. 
- Provide a DNA sample. 

The Court ordered defendant's operating privileges revoked for a period of 2 YEARS followed by ignition interlock for a period of 2 YEARS.  

The Court ordered the defendant to pay a fine of $2400 plus applicable costs, fees, and surcharges (including DNA) during the term of extended supervision.  Cash bond on deposit is to be applied.  Failure to pay shall result in a civil judgment. If revoked from extended supervision, Court ordered that all court costs, fines, fees, and surcharges be paid through collection by the Department of Corrections in an amount or percentage the Department (DOC) determines to be reasonable and as a condition of extended supervision.  DOC shall collect those sums.  Any amount remaining due and owing is subject to civil judgment and/or tax intercept or other means.

20 day appeal rights given.

Preliminary hearing proceeded.  Sworn for the State: Andrew Lamm, Officer for the West Allis Police Department.   State rests.  Defense rests.  Defense motion to dismiss argued and denied. Court found probable cause and bound defendant over for trial.  Original information received and filed; defense counsel requests time to review information with defendant.  Case is adjourned to Branch 45.  Arraignment scheduled for March 18, 2022 at 01:30 pm.

Court ordered defendant TURNED OVER TO Justice Point for SUPERVISION Level 3.  The Court ordered defendant to maintain ABSOLUTE SOBRIETY.  Court ordered no possession or use of controlled substances without a valid prescription.

Defendant James Earl Queen in court with attorney Rosemary Cuevas.  Defendant James Earl Queen in custody.  Brad Alan Vorpahl appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  James Earl Queen appeared by video means with Attorney.  Defendant is advised this case is assigned to Judge Kies, Branch 45. Defendant given a copy of the complaint and advised of maximum penalties, right to counsel and right to a preliminary hearing.  Court reviewed the complaint and found probable cause to hold the defendant for further proceedings.  DEFENDANT DOES NOT QUALIFY FOR PUBLIC DEFENDER REPRESENTATION IF RELEASED FROM CUSTODY.  Defendant waived time limits for Preliminary Hearing.  Preliminary hearing scheduled for February 25, 2022 at 08:30 am.
